abstracts.cdata!:
The program's main objective is to
            halt recent increases in the national rate of infant
            mortality (now at a national average of 16.8 1000 live
            births-and a Northwest Region of Argentina (NOA) and
            Northeast Region of Argentina (NEA) average of 250/00), and
            then reduce it by at least 20 percent at the national level,
            and at least 30 percent in the participating northern
            provinces over a period of 10 years. The first Adaptable
            Program Lending (APL) would cover the nine poorest provinces
            of the NOA and NEA. By the end of loan implementation of
            APLl (5th project year), 80 percent of the targeted
            population would be covered and served by the Maternal and
            Child Health Insurance Program (MCHIP) (more than 600,000
            beneficiaries). Lastly, the project would contribute to
            improving the national-provincial health policy dialogue and
            policy integration, reducing the extreme policy
            fragmentation that characterizes Argentina's health
            sector in the last 30 years. Achieving all 3 objectives
            above would allow the national-provincial policy dialogue to
            shift away from focusing on inputs and center on output and
            increasingly on outcomes.  This Indigenous Peoples Plan
            (IPP) consists of three parts: Social evaluation;
            consultation process; and Matrix shares with Indigenous
            Peoples Plan which is the schedule of activities and
            specific actions to be carried out in the period indicated
            for consensual with indigenous communities during the
            consultation and aims to bring together and strengthen the
            inclusion of indigenous communities to the project. This
            project has macroeconomic risks associated with Argentinas
            economic fragility, and the inherent political risks of
            fiscal and institutional reform governing
            national-provincial relationships. Additional implementation
            risks have been recognized, specific to the investment
            program, and have been taken into account in its design.
            These relate principally to the weak institutional capacity
            of provincial health ministries.
